title: Paul Routledge: Librarians strike so austerity isn’t the final chapter
text:

The public library in working-class Keighley, West Yorkshire, occupies a special place in history.

Opened by the Duke of Devonshire in 1904 amid rejoicing, it was the first in England given by American industrialist Andrew Carnegie.

It was the scene of another first this week: a strike by librarians in protest at cuts in jobs and services by Bradford Metropolitan Council. The massive iron gates were closed while Unite union members picketed outside.

I joined the demonstration in Albert Street to hear their grievances. They have a very good case. The council is cutting almost a million pounds from its libraries and museums budget, and the same next year – a reduction of two-thirds.

Some will close, others turned over to volunteers. Librarians and curators will be made redundant and services ­drastically curtailed.

As Neil Kinnock might say, by a Labour council – a Labour council. And irony of ironies, a council spending £1.4million over the next three years in a bid to be UK City of Culture 2025. National fame, sought at the expense of culture for its own citizens and the jobs of its own employees.

But what’s happening in Bradford is just symptomatic of a national scandal.

Since 2010, funding for libraries, museums and galleries has been slashed by over £400million. More than 700 libraries have closed, and 8,000 staff made redundant.

Osborne austerity may be in its death throes, but it’s taking our national heritage with it.

The government promises new money: too little, too late.

Councillors desperate to balance the books think librarians are a soft target.

But these virgin strikers – it’s their first time on a picket line – are digging in for a long dispute, with two further rounds of stoppages planned.

I support them, because Routledge’s Law states that there is no guarantee of success if you have a go, only a guarantee of failure if you don’t.
